headline: Pete Hegseth’s Mother Accused Her Son of Mistreating Women for Years
abstract: Penelope Hegseth made the accusation in an email to her son in 2018, amid his contentious divorce. She said on Friday that she regretted the email and had apologized to him.
lead_paragraph: The mother of Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for secretary of defense, wrote him an email in 2018 saying he had routinely mistreated women for years and displayed a lack of character.
snippet: Penelope Hegseth made the accusation in an email to her son in 2018, amid his contentious divorce. She said on Friday that she regretted the email and had apologized to him.

headline: Text of the Email That Pete Hegseth’s Mother Sent Him
abstract: Penelope Hegseth sent the email to her son in 2018 as he was in the middle of a divorce from his wife, Samantha.
lead_paragraph: The following is the text of the email that Penelope Hegseth sent to her son, Pete Hegseth, on April 30, 2018. One sentence was redacted by The New York Times for privacy reasons.
snippet: Penelope Hegseth sent the email to her son in 2018 as he was in the middle of a divorce from his wife, Samantha.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 30, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about London’s Smithfield Market incorrectly identified the music ensemble for which Simon Rattle is a conductor. It is the London Symphony Orchestra, not the London Philharmonic Orchestra.
snippet: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 30, 2024.

headline: Styles of Singing
abstract: Oliver Goodridge and Juan Garavito team up on a hairy challenge.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today’s Crossword is the result of circumstances that are quite rare for a Saturday. First, the grid is a collaboration; second, both of its constructors, Oliver Goodridge and Juan Garavito, are making their Times Crossword debuts.
snippet: Oliver Goodridge and Juan Garavito team up on a hairy challenge.

headline: Quote of the Day: Macron Takes an Early Look at a Gleaming Notre-Dame
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “You’ve achieved what was said to be impossible.”
snippet: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 30, 2024.

headline: Taiwan’s President to Rally Tiny Pacific Allies to Counter China
abstract: Lai Ching-te is looking to shore up support from three island nations that are among a dwindling number to keep diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan’s president set off on a mission on Saturday to shore up relations with some of his island democracy’s shrinking band of diplomatic allies: three tiny Pacific Island nations that have taken an outsize importance in Taiwan’s struggle against Chinese efforts to push it off the international stage.
snippet: Lai Ching-te is looking to shore up support from three island nations that are among a dwindling number to keep diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
snippet: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

headline: How a Coffee Fortune Teller Spends His Sundays
abstract: Dr. Honeybrew, as he is known, starts his days with music before brewing Turkish coffee in hot sand and opening his home to guests for a little bit of magic.
lead_paragraph: Uluç Ülgen was born in Istanbul and raised in Minnesota, then he moved to New York in 2012, hoping for a bigger life. A few years later, as “Dr. Honeybrew,” he created the Turkish Coffee Room, a coffee-grounds reading ceremony that is performed out of his living room in the East Village of Manhattan.
snippet: Dr. Honeybrew, as he is known, starts his days with music before brewing Turkish coffee in hot sand and opening his home to guests for a little bit of magic.

headline: The Hole in This Bagel Shop’s Business Model? It’s Too Popular.
abstract: Apollo Bagels in the West Village is drawing lines out the door — and most of the way down the block. Now it’s in a legal fight to stave off eviction.
lead_paragraph: The problem for Apollo Bagels begins outside its cramped West Village corner storefront and ends, at peak hours, more than 100 feet down the block.
snippet: Apollo Bagels in the West Village is drawing lines out the door — and most of the way down the block. Now it’s in a legal fight to stave off eviction.

headline: Undersea Surgeons
abstract: The cables at the heart of the lightspeed, globe-spanning internet run across the grimy, perilous, inaccessible deeps of the sea, in places no one ever sees or visits – until the cables break.
lead_paragraph: The cables at the heart of the lightspeed, globe-spanning internet run across the grimy, perilous, inaccessible deeps of the sea, in places no one ever sees or visits – until the cables break.
snippet: The cables at the heart of the lightspeed, globe-spanning internet run across the grimy, perilous, inaccessible deeps of the sea, in places no one ever sees or visits – until the cables break.

headline: As Cash Fades, Small Retailers Embrace Efforts to Rein In Swipe Fees
abstract: Business owners say card transaction fees are a growing monthly expense, one often passed to consumers. They’re cheering efforts to lower them.
lead_paragraph: Credit and debit card fees were always a big business expense for Patti Riordan, who owns a hobby shop in Lancaster, Ohio. But, she said, since the coronavirus pandemic, they’ve become a pain point.
snippet: Business owners say card transaction fees are a growing monthly expense, one often passed to consumers. They’re cheering efforts to lower them.

headline: What Happens When Undersea Internet Cables Snap?
abstract: The internet is made up of hundreds of cables crossing the floors and the canyons of the earth’s oceans. So what happens when the cables snap? James Glanz, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains what could go wrong with subsea internet cables and how these cables get fixed.
lead_paragraph: The internet is made up of hundreds of cables crossing the floors and the canyons of the earth’s oceans. So what happens when the cables snap? James Glanz, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains what could go wrong with subsea internet cables and how these cables get fixed.
snippet: The internet is made up of hundreds of cables crossing the floors and the canyons of the earth’s oceans. So what happens when the cables snap? James Glanz, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains what could go wrong with subsea ...

headline: As Their Business Flourished, the Marriage Floundered
abstract: Emily and Matthew Hyland found that going into the restaurant business together was not a step to be taken lightly. “Shared visions can change,” he said.
lead_paragraph: In Unhitched, couples tell the stories of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.
snippet: Emily and Matthew Hyland found that going into the restaurant business together was not a step to be taken lightly. “Shared visions can change,” he said.

headline: New Horror Novels That Chill and Entertain
abstract: Our columnist reviews books with lessons about perseverance, an undead girl and bizarre food.
lead_paragraph: Eliza Clark’s SHE’S ALWAYS HUNGRY: Stories (Harper Perennial, 225 pp., paperback, $17.99) is one of the best collections of the year, and I don’t mean just out of this year’s horror offerings, but out of all of 2024’s literary releases.
snippet: Our columnist reviews books with lessons about perseverance, an undead girl and bizarre food.

headline: When Stephen Sondheim Transformed Theater, and Theatergoers, Forever
abstract: An incisive new book, “How Sondheim Can Change Your Life,” examines the extraordinary career of the master of the musical.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, the librettist and director James Lapine asked the composer Stephen Sondheim what sort of musical he wanted to write. The pair were in the early stages of creating “Sunday in the Park With George,” their first collaboration of many, and the response given by the older to the younger man was very Sondheimish indeed. “Theme and variation,” said Sondheim, or as Richard Schoch puts it in his heartwarming essay collection, “How Sondheim Can Change Your Life,” “not, then, a story to be told, but a perspective to be taken.”
snippet: An incisive new book, “How Sondheim Can Change Your Life,” examines the extraordinary career of the master of the musical.

headline: How Do New Streets Get Their Names?
abstract: “You want the street name to be something people would be proud to live on,” says one developer. But no bad vibes, please.
lead_paragraph: Since 1998, Lorrie Parise has come up with the names for hundreds of streets, roads, drives and trails that crisscross two Houston-area planned communities, The Woodlands and The Woodlands Hills. Somewhere along the line, she began to think that naming a baby is easier than naming a street.
snippet: “You want the street name to be something people would be proud to live on,” says one developer. But no bad vibes, please.

headline: How Can We Save the Best Parts of Our Cities?
abstract: A gay bar. A bookstore. Fresh salt air. We could learn to preserve what matters most to people.
lead_paragraph: In April 1969, two months before police officers raided a gay bar on Christopher Street in Greenwich Village called the Stonewall Inn, New York City’s Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the Village a historic district thanks to its rowhouses and spaghetti entanglement of streets, the serendipity of Colonial-era cattle paths and property lines colliding with the city grid.
snippet: A gay bar. A bookstore. Fresh salt air. We could learn to preserve what matters most to people.

headline: Auli’i Cravalho Is More Than a Disney Princess
abstract: “Moana” made her a breakout star. Now Cravalho, at 24, is back in the sequel, while also making her Broadway debut and embracing edgier parts.
lead_paragraph: On a chilly November evening, wearing a light leather jacket and a scarf, Auli’i Cravalho was freezing as she plunged through a pair of gleaming doors into a candlelit bar in Midtown Manhattan.
snippet: “Moana” made her a breakout star. Now Cravalho, at 24, is back in the sequel, while also making her Broadway debut and embracing edgier parts.

headline: Bridget Finn Takes the Helm of Miami’s Big-League Art Fair
abstract: The new director of Art Basel Miami Beach comes from the gallery world. As the art market contracts and rival fairs expand, how will Finn deliver?
lead_paragraph: If you want to be immediately ushered into the back rooms of downtown New York’s pre-eminent art galleries, it helps to be a deep-pocketed collector. Or you could just tag along with Bridget Finn, the new director of Art Basel Miami Beach, as she hopped between TriBeCa galleries on a recent afternoon.
snippet: The new director of Art Basel Miami Beach comes from the gallery world. As the art market contracts and rival fairs expand, how will Finn deliver?

headline: Juliette Binoche Is Taking Christian Louboutin to the Theater
abstract: “I’ve seen this play three times, and it’s five and a half hours long,” said the actress, who stars in the new movie “The Return.”
lead_paragraph: In Homer’s “Odyssey,” Penelope waits 20 years for her husband, Odysseus, to come home after winning the Trojan War.
snippet: “I’ve seen this play three times, and it’s five and a half hours long,” said the actress, who stars in the new movie “The Return.”

headline: Silicon Valley’s Richest Woman Hosts a Day of Innovation. Just Don’t Say Trump.
abstract: As the country’s liberal bubbles mourn the election’s outcome, Laurene Powell Jobs highlighted entrepreneurs’ good work with one rule: “Cheer loudly!”
lead_paragraph: Some billionaires are joining the Trump administration. Others are contemplating leaving the country.
snippet: As the country’s liberal bubbles mourn the election’s outcome, Laurene Powell Jobs highlighted entrepreneurs’ good work with one rule: “Cheer loudly!”

headline: 6 Podcasts That Will Read You a Bedtime Story
abstract: If you’re seeking a respite for your brain at the end of the day, these shows deliver tales that are diverting but uneventful enough to help you doze off.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot that may be keeping you up at night. Sleep problems have been on the rise for years and have spiked since the pandemic alongside other mental health concerns. And if you’re one of the many Americans who lost sleep in the run up to the election, you may not be sleeping much better now that it’s over.
snippet: If you’re seeking a respite for your brain at the end of the day, these shows deliver tales that are diverting but uneventful enough to help you doze off.

headline: Fashion’s Last Great Weirdo
abstract: With a new store in Los Angeles, a Levi’s collaboration and a growing international presence, Kiko Kostadinov is building that rarest thing in fashion: an independent, family-run empire.
lead_paragraph: In the past year, the fashion designer Kiko Kostadinov began to feel that everyone wanted to talk about one thing: money.
snippet: With a new store in Los Angeles, a Levi’s collaboration and a growing international presence, Kiko Kostadinov is building that rarest thing in fashion: an independent, family-run empire.

headline: For Rising Democrats, the Quiet Race to Lead the Party Began Months Ago
abstract: As Kamala Harris dominated attention on the 2024 trail, ambitious Democrats were also blanketing the country, building relationships that could pay dividends in the fight for the party’s future.
lead_paragraph: In Texas, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan paid homage to Beyoncé, a Houston native, and told a room full of Democratic activists about the party’s successes in her state.
snippet: As Kamala Harris dominated attention on the 2024 trail, ambitious Democrats were also blanketing the country, building relationships that could pay dividends in the fight for the party’s future.

headline: How ‘Death Becomes Her’ Changed the Way Movies Look
abstract: The loony 1992 comedy’s visual effects broke new ground (along with Meryl Streep’s neck). With the film’s Broadway musical adaptation, a look at its enduring legacy.
lead_paragraph: A tagline for the 1992 release of “Death Becomes Her” billed the film as “Your basic black comedy.” In truth, it was anything but: A screwball mélange of satire, slapstick and gonzo body horror, the movie would have been notable enough for starring two Oscar-winning actresses, Meryl Streep and Goldie Hawn, as lifelong frenemies who find immortality — and all the curses that come with it — via a magic elixir. (And for the fact that Bruce Willis, a die-hard paragon of broody masculinity, played the hapless, bumbling cuckold caught between them.)
snippet: The loony 1992 comedy’s visual effects broke new ground (along with Meryl Streep’s neck). With the film’s Broadway musical adaptation, a look at its enduring legacy.

headline: How Kennedy Has Worked Abroad to Weaken Global Public Health Policy
abstract: The health secretary pick and his organization have worked around the world to undermine longstanding policies on measles, AIDS and more.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who is in line to lead the Department of Health and Human Services in the next Trump administration, is well-known for promoting conspiracy theories and vaccine skepticism in the United States.
snippet: The health secretary pick and his organization have worked around the world to undermine longstanding policies on measles, AIDS and more.

headline: Flip Taxes: What Can Your Co-op Board Get Away With?
abstract: Transfer fees, a.k.a. flip taxes, typically fund upgrades and improvements in co-op buildings. But how much is too much?
lead_paragraph: Q: In our 10-unit South Harlem co-op, the new board announced an initiative to raise the flip tax from 2 percent to 7 percent of the gross sale price, but has not voted on it. Meanwhile, a sale has been pending for months, waiting for board approval. The seller’s lawyer sent a letter addressing the suspicious timing of the flip tax announcement and delays in the sale. After initially rejecting the buyers, the board is now accepting them — contingent on the sellers placing an extra 5 percent flip tax in escrow for a year, which would allow the board to claim the money if they raise the flip tax. Is this legal?
snippet: Transfer fees, a.k.a. flip taxes, typically fund upgrades and improvements in co-op buildings. But how much is too much?

headline: Turbulence on an Airplane From a Storm Can Start Earlier Than You Think
abstract: This is your captain speaking: You may need to buckle those seatbelts a lot sooner than you’re used to.
lead_paragraph: Rattled nerves and spilled drinks are the most common outcomes of a choppy flight, but intense air turbulence can also cause bodily harm. And while one well-known cause of air turbulence is thunderstorms, it’s poorly understood how far from a tempest shaky conditions are likely to persist.
snippet: This is your captain speaking: You may need to buckle those seatbelts a lot sooner than you’re used to.

headline: After Democratic Losses, a Little-Known Lawmaker Wants to Lead the Party
abstract: State Senator James Skoufis of New York is mounting a long-shot bid for D.N.C. chair, hoping his record of success in Trump country proves persuasive to party insiders.
lead_paragraph: State Senator James Skoufis of New York announced on Saturday what is certain to be a long-shot bid to become chairman of the Democratic National Committee, pitching himself as an outsider candidate who has won in a part of the country where President-elect Donald J. Trump prevailed.
snippet: State Senator James Skoufis of New York is mounting a long-shot bid for D.N.C. chair, hoping his record of success in Trump country proves persuasive to party insiders.

headline: Democrats Weigh Dumping Nadler, Regrouping to Counter Trump
abstract: Some House Democrats want to oust aging committee leaders like Representative Jerrold Nadler in favor of younger lawmakers who they see as better suited to take on the president.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats are considering pushing aside some of their most senior leaders from top posts in the next Congress, driven by a worry that aging members are not up to the task of countering President-elect Donald J. Trump and his loyal Republican allies in Congress.
snippet: Some House Democrats want to oust aging committee leaders like Representative Jerrold Nadler in favor of younger lawmakers who they see as better suited to take on the president.

headline: Israel-Hezbollah Cease-Fire Rests on a Wobbly Linchpin: Lebanon’s Army
abstract: The Lebanese Army is tasked with ensuring that Hezbollah abides by the cease-fire. It has failed at that task before.
lead_paragraph: The fragile peace between Israel and Hezbollah largely hangs on 10,000 soldiers in the Lebanese Army.
snippet: The Lebanese Army is tasked with ensuring that Hezbollah abides by the cease-fire. It has failed at that task before.

headline: Rebels Seize Control Over Most of Syria’s Largest City
abstract: The rapid advance on Aleppo came just four days into a surprise opposition offensive that is the most intense escalation in years in the civil war.
lead_paragraph: Rebels had seized most of Syria’s largest city, Aleppo, as of Saturday, according to a war monitoring group and to fighters who were combing the streets in search of any remaining pockets of government forces.
snippet: The rapid advance on Aleppo came just four days into a surprise opposition offensive that is the most intense escalation in years in the civil war.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,261
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Dec. 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Dec. 1, 2024.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 539
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 1, 2024.

headline: For Canada, Trade Tumult From Trump’s Return Has Begun
abstract: While the president-elect says he will impose a 25 percent tariff on everything Canada exports, Trudeau remains confident about forestalling that outcome.
lead_paragraph: The week began with President-elect Donald J. Trump threatening to impose a 25 percent tariff on everything that Canada exports to the United States. It ended with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau flying down to join him for dinner at Mar-a-Lago.
snippet: While the president-elect says he will impose a 25 percent tariff on everything Canada exports, Trudeau remains confident about forestalling that outcome.

headline: Giving Love
abstract: The act of giving a gift is a vehicle for showing people how you feel. Here are tips to find the perfect present.
lead_paragraph: My dad used to hand-write specific, and often unrealistic, gift wish lists for his children to fulfill before every holiday. When I was in college, he asked me for a $30,000 pontoon boat.
snippet: The act of giving a gift is a vehicle for showing people how you feel. Here are tips to find the perfect present.

headline: Israel Strikes Sites in Lebanon Amid Fragile Cease-Fire
abstract: As the truce appeared to largely hold, a deal appeared far away in Gaza, where an Israeli strike killed dozens, according to a rescue group.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Saturday that it had struck several Hezbollah sites in Lebanon, keeping the country on edge over a fragile cease-fire, as its forces pressed on with their campaign in Gaza with little sign of letting up.
snippet: As the truce appeared to largely hold, a deal appeared far away in Gaza, where an Israeli strike killed dozens, according to a rescue group.

headline: How Our Messed-Up Dating Culture Leads to Loneliness, Anger and Donald Trump
abstract: A generation of resentful young men has arisen from the cultural norm dictating that men must be the breadwinners.
lead_paragraph: Joe Rogan. Elon Musk. Representatives of bro culture are on the ascent, bringing with them an army of disaffected young men. But where did they come from? Many argue that a generation of men are resentful because they have fallen behind women in work and school. I believe this shift would not have been so destabilizing were it not for the fact that our society still has one glass-slippered foot in the world of Cinderella.
snippet: A generation of resentful young men has arisen from the cultural norm dictating that men must be the breadwinners.

headline: New Orleans Knows It May Not Live Forever. We Could All Take a Cue.
abstract: Unlike the other major cities that appear on lists of unsafe places, New Orleans has a striking competitive advantage.
lead_paragraph: A unifying theme of this year’s extremely active Atlantic hurricane season, which officially concludes on Saturday, has been the disbelief echoing from the Blue Ridge Mountains to the Ozark plateau. “I had always felt like we were safe from climate change,” an Asheville, N.C., woman told The Times after Hurricane Helene. “But now this makes me question that maybe there’s nowhere that’s safe.”
snippet: Unlike the other major cities that appear on lists of unsafe places, New Orleans has a striking competitive advantage.

headline: A Job and Community Transform Refugees’ Lives
abstract: The organization doesn’t just teach culinary skills — it provides additional support, such as résumé building and English classes.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Times Opinion’s Giving Guide 2024. Read more in a note from Times Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.
snippet: The organization doesn’t just teach culinary skills — it provides additional support, such as résumé building and English classes.

headline: Reckoning With the Connection Between Brain Injuries and Criminal Behavior
abstract: In the fight to reduce recidivism, we may be ignoring one major element.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Marchell Taylor lay in his windowless, six-by-eight cell in the Denver County Jail. Only 36 days after being released after serving time for drug and robbery convictions, he robbed a Papa John’s and assaulted an employee. Because of his record, Mr. Taylor faced 300 years of imprisonment. He asked himself: Why am I back here?
snippet: In the fight to reduce recidivism, we may be ignoring one major element.

headline: Why I’m Not Giving Up on American Democracy
abstract: The free and decent country that saved my family from Soviet Hungary is now under threat.
lead_paragraph: In his dank Budapest prison cell in the mid-1950s, my father imagined he heard Dvorak’s “New World” Symphony. Though no one in my family had ever set foot in the actual New World, just knowing it existed brought my father solace during his nearly two-year incarceration.
snippet: The free and decent country that saved my family from Soviet Hungary is now under threat.

headline: Note to Democrats: It’s Time to Take Up Your Hammers
abstract: There is a straight line from homeless schoolchildren to Donald Trump’s election victory.
lead_paragraph: I would prefer to live in a world where the recent news that more than 146,000 New York City schoolchildren experienced homelessness during the last school year was regarded as a crisis demanding immediate changes in public policy. But if helping children isn’t enough to move New York’s political leaders to action — and, by all indications, it most certainly is not — they might consider doing it for the sake of the Democratic Party.
snippet: There is a straight line from homeless schoolchildren to Donald Trump’s election victory.

headline: Russia Forges Ahead in Eastern Ukraine, Capturing More Villages in Recent Days
abstract: Russian forces are closing in on two strongholds. The fall of the cities could pave the way for a takeover of the southern part of the Donetsk region, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: Russian troops in eastern Ukraine have seized at least 10 villages and settlements in roughly as many days, according to a group with ties to the Ukrainian Army that maps the battlefield, as Moscow presses on with slow but steady advances that have heightened pressure on Ukraine’s authorities to start cease-fire talks.
snippet: Russian forces are closing in on two strongholds. The fall of the cities could pave the way for a takeover of the southern part of the Donetsk region, analysts said.

headline: Saudi Arabia Leads Pushback Against Global Plastic Treaty
abstract: Delegates from more than 170 countries are working to salvage a treaty that would tackle the growing problem of plastic pollution.
lead_paragraph: A week after Saudi Arabia, the world’s top oil exporter, was accused of being a “wrecking ball” jeopardizing global climate talks, Saudi officials are leading an effort to block a United Nations deal to tackle plastic pollution, negotiators said.
snippet: Delegates from more than 170 countries are working to salvage a treaty that would tackle the growing problem of plastic pollution.

headline: ‘This Was One of the Most Delicious Recipes We Have Made’
abstract: Sarah DiGregorio’s salmon and kimchi skillet, a five-star, five-ingredient dinner to kick-start your taste buds.
lead_paragraph: I can’t remember when I started keeping kimchi in my fridge, and I certainly don’t know what I ever did without it. With a hefty red-lidded jug of spicy, funky fermented napa cabbage kimchi beaming at me, I have the foundation for all sorts of fast, hugely flavorful dinners. Kimchi fried rice. Kimchi noodle soup. These sheet-pan pierogies with brussels sprouts and kimchi, which someone at a holiday party told me is their favorite New York Times Cooking recipe, and this kimchi grilled cheese, which is my favorite grilled cheese.
snippet: Sarah DiGregorio’s salmon and kimchi skillet, a five-star, five-ingredient dinner to kick-start your taste buds.
